prospect.translation[0].definitions[0].d: the possibility that something will happen
prospect.translation[0].definitions[0].e: I see no prospect of things improving here.
There is every prospect (=a strong possibility) of the weather remaining dry this week.
There are good prospects for growth in the retail sector.
There’s a real prospect that England will not qualify for the World Cup.
prospect.translation[0].definitions[1].d: a particular event which will probably or definitely happen in the future – used especially when you want to talk about how you feel about it
prospect.translation[0].definitions[1].e: He relishes the prospect of a fight.
She wasn’t exactly overjoyed at the prospect of looking after her niece.
be excited/alarmed/concerned etc at the prospect (of something)
The prospect of marriage terrified Alice.
Greeks face the prospect of new general elections next month.
prospect.translation[0].definitions[2].d: a person, job, plan etc that has a good chance of success in the future
prospect.translation[0].definitions[3].d: a view of a wide area of land, especially from a high place
prospect.translation[0].note_box[0].head: – Meaning 2: a particular event which will probably or definitely happen in the future – used especially when you want to talk about how you feel about it
prospect.translation[0].note_box[0].sect: It is a pretty daunting prospect, being on stage for forty minutes.
Driving through London in a strange car was a terrifying prospect.
Many Britons face the grim prospect of having their home repossessed.
We were to be her guardians. This was an exciting prospect.
A journey of that length was not an attractive prospect.
Now they face the prospect of unemployment.
She would have to speak to him. She didn’t relish the prospect.
I dread the prospect of staying here while you’re away.
be excited/thrilled/delighted etc at the prospect (of something)
I was excited at the prospect of going to Washington.
be alarmed/appalled/upset etc at the prospect (of something)
She was secretly appalled at the prospect of being looked after by her aunt.
prospect.translation[1].definitions[0].d: to examine an area of land or water, in order to find gold, silver, oil etc
prospect.translation[1].definitions[0].e: The company is prospecting for gold in Alaska.
prospect.translation[1].definitions[1].d: to look for something, especially business opportunities
prospect.translation[2].definitions[0].d: a possibility that something which you hope for will happen soon
prospect.translation[2].definitions[0].e: There is little real prospect of significant economic growth.
prospect.translation[2].definitions[1].e: firms offering the best prospects for increasing productivity, profitability, and expansion
In Singapore, investors remain optimistic about prospects for the economy.
prospect.translation[2].definitions[2].d: something that is possible or is likely to happen in the future
prospect.translation[2].definitions[2].e: The prospect of still higher unemployment as growth slows is causing great concern.
prospect.translation[2].definitions[3].d: a person, job, plan etc that has a good chance of success in the future
prospect.translation[2].definitions[3].e: Radio is an exciting prospect: the forthcoming deregulation of the industry and an expected boom in advertising revenues is finally making the City take notice.
prospect.translation[2].definitions[4].d: someone who is not a customer yet, but may become one in the future
prospect.translation[2].definitions[4].e: Mercedes-Benz has kept its reputation by reminding prospects that its vehicles are ‘engineered like no other car in the world.’
prospect.translation[3].definitions[0].d: to examine an area of land or water, in order to find gold, silver, oil etc
prospect.translation[3].definitions[0].e: Anglo-United was prospecting for gold in the area in the early eighties.
